ground_truth: Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door and stares at Gittes for a long moment before he gently tugs the car door closed. Evelyn remains unperturbed as he drives off into the Wilshire traffic, leaving her looking after him. Gittes goes through the door to the Secretary, who looks up, recognizes him again, and is not happy to see him; she immediately gets up and goes into the inner office. Gittes turns and strolls around the office, stopping as he spots a photo of the man with the cane, whom he had seen photos of earlier, standing high in the mountains near a pass. Gittes pulls out a cigarette case, offers the Secretary one, but she refuses. He lights up and begins to hum 'The Way You Look Tonight,' while strolling along the wall looking at more photographs, where he spots several photos of a much younger Mulwray, along with Julian Cross. Still humming, Gittes turns to the Secretary, who gets up, annoyed, and goes into Yelburton's inner office. Gittes goes back to the photographs and hears a scratching sound, apparently coming from just outside the outer door. He moves quickly to it, hesitates, and swiftly opens the door to find workmen scraping away Mulwray's name on the outer door, looking up at him in some surprise. The Secretary returns and sees the workman on the floor as Gittes heads toward the door and nods graciously, heading into Yelburton's office, where there is a subtle but perceptible difference in Yelburton's attitude. Gittes nods and smiles, leaving an unsmiling Yelburton, enters, and drops his hat on Sophie's desk. Sophie tries to tell him something, but Gittes goes on into his office, where she looks up when he enters. Gittes moves to his desk, barely breaking stride at the sight of her, sits, and smokes. Gittes buzzes Sophie, Evelyn nods, she lights another cigarette, and signs it. Cross is visibly surprised and nods. Gittes glances down at the fish whose isinglass eye is glazed over with the heat of cooking, and he laughs and shrugs. Cross starts to reply, but there is the sound of a mariachi band as some men in formation clear a bluff about a hundred yards off, dressed like Spanish dons on horseback. Cross shakes his head, looks to Gittes in some real surprise, and then hatefully. Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans, Gittes approaches one of the clerks at a desk, whose droopy eyes widen a little at a snotty remark. Gittes smiles, regards the clerk's back a moment, then goes to the stacks, where he sees the clerk turn to another and say something, prompting the second clerk to get on the phone.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Evelyn stabilizes herself on the open automobile door and gazes at Gittes for a lengthy instant before he softly pulls the automobile door shut. Evelyn remains composed as he maneuvers off into the Wilshire traffic, leaving her observing after him. Gittes proceeds through the entry to the Secretary, who glances up, identifies him again, and is not pleased to see him; she promptly rises and goes into the inner office. Gittes rotates and saunters around the office, halting as he notices a photograph of the gentleman with the cane, whom he had viewed pictures of earlier, standing elevated in the peaks near a pass. Gittes extracts a cigarette case, presents the Secretary one, but she declines. He ignites and commences to murmur 'The Way You Look Tonight,' while sauntering along the wall observing more pictures, where he notices several photographs of a much younger Mulwray, along with Julian Cross. Still murmuring, Gittes turns to the Secretary, who rises, irritated, and goes into Yelburton's inner office. Gittes returns to the pictures and detects a scratching noise, seemingly emanating from just outside the outer entryway. He moves swiftly to it, hesitates, and quickly opens the entryway to discover workers scraping away Mulwray's name on the outer entryway, glancing up at him in some astonishment. The Secretary returns and perceives the worker on the floor as Gittes heads toward the entryway and nods graciously, heading into Yelburton's office, where there is a subtle but noticeable shift in Yelburton's demeanor. Gittes nods and grins, leaving an unsmiling Yelburton, enters, and places his hat on Sophie's desk. Sophie attempts to inform him of something, but Gittes continues into his office, where she glances up when he enters. Gittes advances to his desk, scarcely breaking stride at the sight of her, sits, and smokes. Gittes buzzes Sophie, Evelyn nods, she ignites another cigarette, and signs it. Cross is evidently astonished and nods. Gittes peers down at the fish whose isinglass eye is glazed over with the heat of cooking, and he chuckles and shrugs. Cross begins to respond, but there is the sound of a mariachi ensemble as some men in formation clear a bluff about a hundred yards off, attired like Spanish dons on horseback. Cross shakes his head, looks to Gittes in some genuine astonishment, and then resentfully. Dim and quiet except for the whirring of fans, Gittes approaches one of the clerks at a desk, whose droopy eyes enlarge a little at a snotty comment. Gittes grins, considers the clerk's back a moment, then goes to the stacks, where he observes the clerk turn to another and say something, prompting the second clerk to get on the telephone.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door, staring at Gittes before he gently shuts it. She remains unperturbed as he drives away into Wilshire traffic. Gittes enters the Secretary's office, where she recognizes him and, displeased, heads to the inner office. He strolls around, spotting a photo of the man with the cane in the mountains. Offering a cigarette to the Secretary, which she declines, he hums 'The Way You Look Tonight,' observing more photos of a younger Mulwray with Julian Cross. Still humming, Gittes turns to the annoyed Secretary, who goes into Yelburton's office. Hearing a scratching sound outside, Gittes opens the door to find workmen erasing Mulwray's name. The Secretary sees the workman as Gittes enters Yelburton's office, noting a subtle change in Yelburton's demeanor. Gittes nods, leaving an unsmiling Yelburton, and goes into his own office. Sophie tries to speak to him, but he proceeds to his desk, sits, and smokes. He buzzes Sophie; Evelyn nods, lights another cigarette, and signs it. Cross is surprised and nods as Gittes notices the fish's glazed eye, laughs, and shrugs. Cross begins to respond, but a mariachi band in the distance draws his attention, surprising and angering him. In a dark, quiet room, Gittes approaches a clerk at a desk, whose eyes widen at a remark. Gittes smiles, watches the clerk, then moves to the stacks as another clerk makes a phone call.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Evelyn steadies herself on the car door, staring at Gittes, who gently closes it and drives into Wilshire traffic. Gittes enters where the Secretary, displeased to see him, goes to the inner office. He strolls the office, noticing a photo of the man with a cane and offers the Secretary a smoke, which she declines. Humming 'The Way You Look Tonight,' he sees photos of a younger Mulwray with Julian Cross. Annoyed, the Secretary enters Yelburton's office. Gittes investigates a scratching sound at the door and finds workmen removing Mulwray's name. The Secretary returns as Gittes nods and enters Yelburton's office, where Yelburton's demeanor subtly changes. Gittes nods, smiles, and drops his hat on Sophie's desk before entering his office to smoke. He buzzes Sophie; Evelyn nods, lights a cigarette, and signs. Cross is surprised and nods. Gittes laughs at the fish's glaze, as a mariachi band appears. Cross looks at Gittes with surprise and hate. In the dark, Gittes approaches a clerk whose eyes widen at a remark. Smiling, Gittes moves to the stacks while a second clerk phones.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Evelyn, feeling the weight of the moment, steadies herself with a firm grip on the open car door as she fixes her gaze intently on Gittes for what seems an extended moment of silence. This exchange hangs in the air until Gittes, with gentle firmness, pulls the car door shut. Unshaken by the parting, Evelyn stands resolute as he merges into the bustling flow of Wilshire traffic, leaving her behind. As Gittes continues, he passes through the entrance to the Secretary, who, upon looking up and recognizing him, exhibits visible displeasure at his unexpected presence. She quickly rises, without any delay, and proceeds into the inner sanctum of the office. Meanwhile, Gittes meanders around the office space, his attention caught by a photograph of a man with a cane—a familiar face he had observed in photos earlier—who is depicted standing proudly amid the towering mountains near a scenic pass.

Gittes, ever the gentleman, retrieves a cigarette case from his pocket and extends an offering to the Secretary, who declines with a subtle gesture. He lights his own cigarette, and as tendrils of smoke curl upward, he begins to hum the familiar tune of 'The Way You Look Tonight.' Leisurely, he continues his exploratory stroll along the wall, his eyes catching several photographs of a youthful Mulwray alongside Julian Cross. The melody still on his lips, Gittes turns his attention to the Secretary, whose growing irritation is evident as she rises once again and disappears into Yelburton's more private office quarters. Returning his focus to the photographs, Gittes's senses are suddenly piqued by a peculiar scratching noise emanating from beyond the outer door. Moving swiftly yet cautiously, he reaches the door, hesitating briefly before opening it with swift determination to reveal workmen in the act of erasing Mulwray's name from the glass. The workmen pause, momentarily startled by Gittes's unexpected appearance.

As the Secretary makes her way back, she notices the workman positioned on the floor, while Gittes graciously nods and advances toward the entrance of Yelburton's office. Inside, there is a subtle, almost imperceptible shift in Yelburton's demeanor. Gittes acknowledges this change with a nod and a smile, leaving Yelburton unsmiling behind as he places his hat on Sophie's desk. Sophie, attempting to communicate something important, finds herself momentarily ignored as Gittes moves purposefully into his office, her eyes following him upon entry. Gittes approaches his desk with unbroken stride, takes a seat, and indulges in another cigarette. He signals to Sophie, with Evelyn nodding in agreement, she kindles another cigarette, and signs a form with a flourish. Cross reacts with visible surprise, nodding in acknowledgment as Gittes casts a glance toward the fish, its glassy isinglass eye dulled by the cooking heat, prompting him to laugh and shrug it off. Cross begins to respond, but their conversation is interrupted by the lively rhythm of a mariachi band as a group of men on horseback, dressed in flamboyant Spanish-inspired attire, clear a bluff a mere hundred yards away. Cross, taken aback, looks from the unexpected spectacle to Gittes with an expression morphing from surprise to disdain.

In the dim and quiet atmosphere, punctuated only by the gentle whirring of fans, Gittes approaches one of the clerks stationed at a desk, whose drooping eyelids slightly widen at a snide remark. Gittes, unfazed, offers a cordial smile as he regards the clerk's back momentarily before proceeding to the stacks. There, he notices the first clerk turning to a colleague, whispering something that prompts the second clerk to pick up the phone, setting off a chain of actions behind the scenes.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Evelyn, acutely aware of the gravity of the moment, steadies herself with a firm and unwavering grip on the open car door, her eyes fixing intently on Gittes for what feels like an extended, lingering moment of silence. This charged exchange hangs heavily in the air until Gittes, with a gentle yet firm resolve, pulls the car door shut. Unfazed by the parting, Evelyn remains standing, resolute and unaffected, as he merges seamlessly into the ceaseless and bustling flow of Wilshire traffic, leaving her behind. As Gittes continues on his way, he makes his passage through the entrance to the Secretary, who, upon raising her eyes and recognizing him, displays visible displeasure at his unexpected and unannounced arrival. She rises swiftly, wasting no time, and makes her way into the more private inner sanctum of the office. Meanwhile, Gittes leisurely meanders around the office space, his attention drawn by a photograph depicting a man with a cane—a familiar face he had noticed in earlier photographs—standing proudly amidst the towering grandeur of mountains near a scenic mountain pass.

Gittes, embodying the demeanor of a courteous gentleman, retrieves a sleek cigarette case from his pocket and offers a cigarette to the Secretary, who declines with a subtle yet clear gesture. He then lights his own cigarette, and as delicate tendrils of smoke curl upward, he begins to hum the familiar and melodic tune of 'The Way You Look Tonight.' Leisurely continuing his exploratory stroll along the wall, his eyes are caught by a collection of several photographs of a younger Mulwray posing alongside Julian Cross. The melody still lingering on his lips, Gittes shifts his attention back to the Secretary, whose growing irritation becomes palpable as she rises once again and disappears into Yelburton's even more private office quarters. Redirecting his focus back to the photographs, Gittes's senses are suddenly alerted to a peculiar scratching sound emanating from the direction beyond the outer door. With a quick yet cautious pace, he approaches the door, hesitating momentarily before opening it with determined swiftness to reveal workmen in the midst of erasing Mulwray's name from the glass. The workmen pause, momentarily startled and taken aback by Gittes's unexpected entrance.

As the Secretary makes her way back, she notices the workman positioned on the floor, while Gittes graciously nods and proceeds toward the entrance of Yelburton's office. Once inside, there is a subtle, almost imperceptible shift in Yelburton's demeanor. Gittes acknowledges this change with a knowing nod and a smile, leaving Yelburton unsmiling and silently pondering behind as he places his hat ceremoniously on Sophie's desk. Sophie, attempting to communicate something of importance, finds herself momentarily ignored as Gittes moves purposefully into his office, her attentive eyes following him as he enters. Gittes approaches his desk with an unbroken, confident stride, takes his seat with a sense of familiarity, and indulges in lighting yet another cigarette. He signals to Sophie, who, with Evelyn nodding in agreement, kindles another cigarette and proceeds to sign a form with a flourish. Cross, reacting with visible surprise, nods in acknowledgment as Gittes casts a glance toward the fish, its glassy isinglass eye dulled by the heat of cooking, causing him to laugh and casually shrug it off. Cross begins to form a response, but their conversation is suddenly interrupted by the lively, infectious rhythm of a mariachi band as a group of men on horseback, clad in flamboyant Spanish-inspired attire, clear a bluff just a mere hundred yards away. Cross, taken aback and visibly surprised, shifts his gaze from the unexpected spectacle to Gittes with an expression that evolves from initial surprise to clear disdain.

In the dim and quietly atmospheric setting, punctuated only by the gentle whirring of overhead fans, Gittes approaches one of the clerks stationed at a desk, whose drooping eyelids widen slightly at a snide and cutting remark. Gittes, entirely unfazed by the subtle reaction, offers a cordial and reassuring smile as he momentarily regards the clerk's back before proceeding toward the stacks. There, he observes the first clerk turning discreetly to a colleague, whispering something that prompts the second clerk to pick up the phone, setting off a subtle and orchestrated chain of actions occurring behind the scenes.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Evelyn supports herself gently on the edge of the open car door, her gaze fixed on Gittes for an extended moment as if trying to convey unspoken words or emotions through the intensity of her stare. Meanwhile, Gittes, maintaining a composed demeanor, carefully guides the car door to a soft close, ensuring not to disturb Evelyn's poise. As he drives away into the bustling flow of Wilshire traffic, the vehicle smoothly merges with other cars, leaving Evelyn standing there, her eyes following the car until it becomes just another part of the city's rhythm. Inside a building, Gittes strides through a door leading to a reception area where sitting at a desk, the Secretary looks up from her work. Recognition crosses her face, and an immediate shift in demeanor indicates her displeasure at his unexpected return. Without delay, she rises from her chair, swiftly moving through another door into the inner sanctum of the office, leaving Gittes momentarily alone in the space. Taking the opportunity to explore, Gittes meanders leisurely around the office. His movements come to a halt when his attention is drawn to a photograph featuring a man with a cane, someone familiar from photos he had seen previously, captured standing proudly in the high mountains near a distinctive pass. Gittes retrieves a cigarette case from his pocket, smoothly presenting a cigarette to the Secretary as she re-emerges but her hand declines the offer. With practiced ease, he lights his own cigarette, the flame briefly illuminating his features before an aromatic cloud envelopes him. A melodic hum escapes his lips as he begins serenading the room with 'The Way You Look Tonight,' his body moving in sync with the tune as he continues to examine the wall adorned with photographs. Among them, he discovers images depicting a much younger version of Mulwray alongside Julian Cross, a discovery that holds his attention until the Secretary, clearly perturbed by his presence and demeanor, rises once again to retreat into Yelburton's inner office. Gittes redirects his focus back to the photographs, his reflective state interrupted by an unexpected scratching noise emanating from the vicinity of the outer door. Reacting with swift curiosity, he approaches the door, his hand hesitating momentarily before he decisively swings it open. There, he confronts workmen who are in the midst of erasing Mulwray's name from the door, an alteration that leads them to glance up at him with mild surprise at the intrusion. The Secretary returns once more, catching sight of the workmen where one is sprawled, a detail that prompts Gittes to proceed toward the next office with a polite nod. As he enters Yelburton's office, a subtle yet noticeable shift in Yelburton's demeanor informs him of a change in attitude. Gittes responds with a nod and a smile that seems to linger in the air, juxtaposed against Yelburton's unsmiling countenance. Transitioning seamlessly into the next space, Gittes deposits his hat on Sophie's desk with a casual air. Sophie attempts to communicate something urgent to him, but Gittes, unfazed, continues into his office, his pace unaltered by whatever awaits him inside. Once in his office, he moves directly to his desk, his stride and purpose uninterrupted by the presence of anyone or any unexpected sight. Settling into his chair, he indulges in the soothing ritual of smoking, the tendrils of smoke curling upwards languidly. Buzzing Sophie, he receives acknowledgment from Evelyn, who quietly nods, her fingers expertly lighting another cigarette before signing something, a small act of routine yet laced with significance. Nearby, Cross's surprise is apparent, his nod acknowledging a silent understanding or realization. Gittes's eyes momentarily drift to a fish on display, its isinglass eye appearing glazed from cooking heat, prompting a wry laugh and a nonchalant shrug from him. Cross seems on the verge of a response, but the unexpected sound of a mariachi band steals the focus, as a procession of men in formation becomes visible, clearing a bluff approximately a hundred yards away. They are clad in traditional attire reminiscent of Spanish dons on horseback, their appearance both anachronistic and vibrant against the landscape. This unexpected spectacle elicits a headshake from Cross, his gaze shifting to Gittes, initially tinged with surprise which swiftly morphs into a more sinister hatefulness. In the now dim and quiet office, with only the steady whirring of fans punctuating the silence, Gittes approaches a clerk seated at a desk. The clerk's droopy eyes widen slightly in reaction to a snotty remark made by Gittes, whose face breaks into a smile, lingering a moment to observe the clerk’s back before diverting his path toward the stacks. From this vantage point, Gittes observes the clerk's interaction with another, noticing as the second clerk discreetly picks up the phone, a subtle communication passing between them that does not escape Gittes's notice.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door, exchanges a lingering look with Gittes, and watches him drive away into Wilshire traffic. Gittes enters the office, where the Secretary, unhappy to see him, promptly heads into the inner office. He leisurely examines the photographs on the walls, ultimately recognizing a photo of a man with a cane as well as several pictures of a younger Mulwray with Julian Cross. Humming 'The Way You Look Tonight,' he offers the Secretary a cigarette, which she declines, and continues his inspection until he hears a scratching sound near the outer door. Opening it swiftly, he discovers workmen removing Mulwray's name, surprising both him and the Secretary, who returns just as he nods graciously and proceeds to Yelburton's office. There, he perceives a subtle shift in Yelburton's demeanor, exchanges nods, and enters, passing Sophie to his own office where he takes a seat at his desk. Amidst the transition, Evelyn lights another cigarette, and Cross appears visibly surprised before nodding. Gittes notices a cooked fish with a glazed eye, laughs, and shrugs as Cross reacts with surprise and resentment. Meanwhile, a mariachi band becomes audible as men on horseback appear, dressed like Spanish dons, further surprising Cross. Gittes approaches a clerk at a desk, who reacts to his remark, prompting a second clerk to make a phone call as Gittes moves toward the stacks.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door and stares at Gittes for a long moment before he gently tugs the car door closed, leaving behind the bustling scene of Los Angeles. Evelyn remains unperturbed as he drives off into the Wilshire traffic, a major thoroughfare known for its iconic Miracle Mile district featuring art deco architecture, leaving her looking after him. Gittes goes through the door to the Secretary, who looks up, recognizes him again, and is not happy to see him; she immediately gets up and goes into the inner office. Gittes turns and strolls around the office, stopping as he spots a photo of the man with the cane, whom he had seen photos of earlier, standing high in the Sierra Nevada mountains near a pass, a popular hiking destination known for its breathtaking views. Gittes pulls out a cigarette case, offers the Secretary one, but she refuses. He lights up and begins to hum "The Way You Look Tonight," a classic song by Jerome Kern and Dorothy Fields that won an Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1936, while strolling along the wall looking at more photographs, where he spots several photos of a much younger Mulwray, along with Julian Cross, a powerful figure in Los Angeles business circles. Still humming, Gittes turns to the Secretary, who gets up, annoyed, and goes into Yelburton's inner office. Gittes goes back to the photographs and hears a scratching sound, apparently coming from just outside the outer door. He moves quickly to it, hesitates, and swiftly opens the door to find workmen scraping away Mulwray's name, famously associated with a controversial water project, on the outer door, looking up at him in some surprise. The Secretary returns and sees the workman on the floor as Gittes heads toward the door and nods graciously, heading into Yelburton's office, where there is a subtle but perceptible difference in Yelburton's attitude, a man known for his political connections. Gittes nods and smiles, leaving an unsmiling Yelburton, enters, and drops his hat on Sophie's desk, which had a plaque indicating her long service as a dedicated administrative assistant. Sophie tries to tell him something, but Gittes goes on into his office, where she looks up when he enters. Gittes moves to his desk, barely breaking stride at the sight of her, sits, and smokes. Gittes buzzes Sophie, Evelyn nods, she lights another cigarette, and signs it. Cross, a man with considerable influence in the city's development, is visibly surprised and nods. Gittes glances down at the fish whose isinglass eye is glazed over with the heat of cooking, and he laughs and shrugs. Cross starts to reply, but there is the sound of a mariachi band, often heard at celebrations in Southern California due to the region's large Hispanic community, as some men in formation clear a bluff about a hundred yards off, dressed like Spanish dons on horseback. Cross shakes his head, looks to Gittes in some real surprise, and then hatefully. Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans, Gittes approaches one of the clerks at a desk, whose droopy eyes widen a little at a snotty remark. Gittes smiles, regards the clerk's back a moment, then goes to the stacks, a place filled with documents detailing the city's intricate land deals, where he sees the clerk turn to another and say something, prompting the second clerk to get on the phone.

Gittes turns and strolls around the office stopping as he spots a photo of the man with the cane whom he had seen photos of earlier standing high in the mountains near a pass. Gittes pulls out a cigarette case offers the Secretary one but she refuses. He lights up and begins to hum 'The Way You Look Tonight' while strolling along the wall looking at more photographs where he spots several photos of a much younger Mulwray along with Julian Cross. Still humming Gittes turns to the Secretary who gets up annoyed and goes into Yelburton's inner office. Gittes goes back to the photographs and hears a scratching sound apparently coming from just outside the outer door. He moves quickly to it hesitates and swiftly opens the door to find workmen scraping away Mulwray's name on the outer door looking up at him in some surprise. The Secretary returns and sees the workman on the floor as Gittes heads toward the door and nods graciously heading into Yelburton's office where there is a subtle but perceptible difference in Yelburton's attitude. Gittes nods and smiles leaving an unsmiling Yelburton enters and drops his hat on Sophie's desk. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. Sophie tries to tell him something but Gittes goes on into his office where she looks up when he enters. Gittes moves to his desk barely breaking stride at the sight of her sits and smokes. Gittes buzzes. Sophie. Evelyn nods. she lights another cigarette and signs it. Cross is visibly surprised and nods. Gittes glances down at the fish whose isinglass eye is glazed over with the heat of cooking and he laughs and shrugs. Cross starts to reply but there is the sound of a mariachi band as some men in formation clear a bluff about a hundred yards off dressed like Spanish dons on horseback. Cross shakes his head looks to Gittes in some real surprise and then hatefully. Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans. Gittes approaches one of the clerks at a desk whose droopy eyes widen a little at a snotty remark. Gittes smiles regards the clerk's back a moment then goes to the stacks where he sees the clerk turn to another and say something prompting the second clerk to get on the phone.

Evelyn remains unperturbed as he drives off into the Wilshire traffic leaving her looking after him. Gittes goes through the door to the Secretary who looks up recognizes him again and is not happy to see him. she immediately gets up and goes into the inner office. Gittes turns and strolls around the office stopping as he spots a photo of the man with the cane whom he had seen photos of earlier standing high in the mountains near a pass. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Bianca balances herself on the swinging gate and gazes at Linus for a brief moment before he softly pushes the gate shut. Bianca remains composed as he zooms off into the Broadway lanes, leaving her watching him depart. Linus strolls through the portal to the Assistant, who glances up, identifies him once more, and is displeased to notice him; she promptly rises and heads into the back chamber. Linus wanders and meanders around the chamber, pausing as he catches a glimpse of a portrait of the woman with the umbrella, whom he had viewed images of previously, standing tall in the valleys near a gorge. Linus extracts a candy box, offers the Assistant one, but she declines. He strikes a match and starts to whistle 'Moon River,' while sauntering alongside the wall inspecting more pictures, where he notices numerous images of a much younger Bailey, alongside Dominic Fields. Still whistling, Linus turns to the Assistant, who stands up, irritated, and proceeds into Bronson's back chamber. Linus returns to the pictures and detects a rustling noise, seemingly emanating from right outside the entryway. He dashes swiftly to it, pauses, and swiftly swings open the entrance to discover gardeners scraping away Bailey's title on the front plaque, peering at him with mild astonishment. The Assistant reappears and observes the gardener on the tiles as Linus strides toward the entrance and nods politely, entering Bronson's chamber, where there's a subtle but noticeable alteration in Bronson's demeanor. Linus nods and grins, exiting a stern Bronson, enters, and drops his scarf on Marcie's table. Marcie attempts to convey something to him, but Linus continues into his study, where she glances up upon his entrance. Linus approaches his table, hardly pausing at the sight of her, sits, and puffs. Linus dials Marcie, Bianca acknowledges, she ignites another match, and stamps it out. Fields is overtly astonished and nods. Linus peers down at the painting whose acrylic eye is dulled over with the rays of sunlight, and he chuckles and shrugs. Fields begins to comment, but there is the melody of a jazz orchestra as some women in formation clear a knoll about a hundred meters away, clad like French aviators on bicycles. Fields shakes his head, stares at Linus with genuine bewilderment, and then bitterly. Dim and still apart from the whirring of machinery, Linus approaches one of the typists at a station, whose droopy gaze brights a tad at a sarcastic jest. Linus grins, regards the typist's outline briefly, then ventures to the shelves, where he observes the typist turn to another and murmur something, prompting the second typist to pick up the receiver.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Evelyn watches Gittes leave in his car, then he enters an office, where the Secretary is displeased to see him. Gittes examines photographs, spotting one of the man with the cane. Ignoring the Secretary's refusal of a cigarette, he hums while looking at more photos of a younger Mulwray with Julian Cross. Despite the Secretary's annoyance, Gittes investigates a noise and finds workmen removing Mulwray's name from the door. He acknowledges the Secretary and proceeds to Yelburton's office, where Yelburton's demeanor subtly changes. Ignoring Sophie's attempt to speak, Gittes enters his office, smokes, and interacts with Cross, who is surprised by mariachi music from horseback riders. Amidst the subdued office setting, Gittes encounters a clerk whose reaction prompts a phone conversation.
